Because we have not re-run the experiments yet I cannot say for sure,
but I=
 would guess the effect to be minimal because (1) both HyperNEAT
and PNEAT =
ran under same condition and (2) prior experiments have
shown crossover in =
NEAT to improve performance marginally but not
dramatically.

ken

 that were reached in

those

> > He=
y Jeff,
> > 
> > Yeah, it looks like you hit the nail on the head.  Right n=
ow, it
> > either completely chooses one parent or the other, but putting t=
hat
> > code inside of the loop will make it treat each gene individually
>=
 > (this will perform real crossover).
> > 
> > I'm going to put in the cha=
nge and see how it changes my experiments.
> >  Assuming it doesn't break a=
nything, I'll roll this into the next
> > version.  If it affects the resul=
ts in a negative way, I'll make a
> > parameter for it so you can choose to=
 use crossover or not.
> > 
> > Thanks for the find!
> >

> > --- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >>> Well yes this =
is exactly what it has to be. Note that
randomChoice has
> >>> to be random=
 every time you refer to it. If it is not random (i.e.
> >>> outside the bi=
g loop) then you choose links from either parent.
But if
> >>> it is inside=
 the loop, then you choose a gene randomly from either
> >>> parent. Check =
this out and you will have a clearer picture if
there is
> >>> a bug or not=
. 
> >> 
> >> Thanks Petar. I am confident that HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses the p=
arent
> > outside
> >> the loop, and thus grabs all links from either paren=
t1 or parent2.
> > What I am
> >> trying to find out is whether this is by =
design, or if it is a bug.
> >> 
> >> Do you (or anyone else) happen to kno=
w how it works in other NEAT
> > packages,
> >> in particular Ken's origina=
l NEAT code? My guess is that we are
> > supposed to
> >> be grabbing some =
links from parent1 and some other links from
parent2,
> >> instead of one o=
r the other. I can go check those packages, of
> > course, but I
> >> won't=
 be able to do that for a little while and was wondering if any
> > of you
=
> >> knew off the top of your heads.
> >> 
> >>> But the cloning issue is a=
 deeper one. In this case you must ensure
> >>> that individuals should not=
 mate with themselves or such ones that
> >>> have zero compatibility dista=
nce. Or at least try a few hundred
times
> >>> to find a different mate :) =
Hey, I say this to all users. Don't use
> >>> rand(), fuck that, use the Me=
rsenne Twister instead. I noticed
that in
> >>> enhances performance!
> >> =

> >> Fair enough, but right now I am more focused on the more
immediate is=
sue
> >> above. Thanks for the suggestions, though. I will delve into them
=
when I
> >> resolve the other issue.
> >> 
> >> Thanks. Jeff. 
> >>> 
> >>>=
 Peter
> >>> 
> >>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote=
:
> >>>> 
> >>>> Hi Petar-
> >>>> 
> >>>> Thanks for the reply. I do not ha=
ve a (non-HyperNEAT) NEAT package
> >>> around.
> >>>> Can you let me know =
if your NEAT implementation is different than
> >>> what I
> >>>> report be=
low?
> >>>> 
> >>>> I am using Jason's HyperNEAT 2.5 package available here=
:
> >>>> 
> >>>> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html
> >>>> 
> >>>> If yo=
u download the package, the key file is:
> >>>> HyperNEAT/NEAT/src/NEAT_Gen=
eticIndividual.cpp
> >>>> 
> >>>> I am attaching it, but I don't know how t=
hat works with the yahoo
> >>> group.
> >>>> 
> >>>> Crossover occurs in th=
is constructor:
> >>>> 
> >>>>     
> >>> GeneticIndividual::GeneticIndivid=
ual(shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual>
> >>>> parent1,shared_ptr<GeneticIndividu=
al> parent2,bool
> >>> mate_multipoint_avg)
> >>>> 
> >>>> The following li=
ne occurs outside of the loop that goes through
each
> >>> link:
> >>>> 
> =
>>>>  bool chooseFirstParent =3D (randomChoice<=3Dparent1->getFitness());
>=
 >>>>  
> >>>> Then, inside the loop for each link:
> >>>> 
> >>>>         =
            if (chooseFirstParent)
> >>>>                     {
> >>>>     =
                    addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link1));
> >>>>               =
      }
> >>>>                     else
> >>>>                     {
> >>>>=
                         addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
> >>>>          =
           }
> >>>>  
> >>>> So, it seems that *all* the links will be grab=
bed from one
parent or
> >>> the
> >>>> other. Is that how it works in othe=
r versions of NEAT?
> >>>> 
> >>>> 
> >>>> 
> >>>> Cheers,
> >>>> Jeff Clun=
e

> >>>>> From: petar_chervensk=
i <petar_chervenski@>
> >>>>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoog=
roups.com>
> >>>>> Date: Sun, 09 Nov 2008 20:14:32 -0000
> >>>>> To: "neat@=
yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> >>>>> Subject: [neat] Re: Crossov=
er doing anything in HyperNEAT and
> >>> PNEAT?
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> Hi Jeff, 
=
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> Well I don't know about the exact implementations of Hyper=
NEAT you
> >>> are
> >>>>> using (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additi=
ve mutations
> >>>>> disabled), but in principle crossover should choose ge=
nes randomly
> >>>>> from both parents as it builds the offspring genome, t=
he child. In
> >>>>> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actual=
ly do a
> >>> regular
> >>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other n=
etworks based on the
> >>>>> substrate configuration. That is, you only mat=
e and mutate the
> >>> CPPNs.
> >>>>> But in the case you get lots of indiv=
iduals with equal fitness, I
> >>>>> guess these individuals are clones. Pe=
rhaps the code frequently
> >>>>> chooses the same individuals for mating? =
You can try to avoid this
> >>> by
> >>>>> introducing a loop in which you =
try candidates for a "father" that
> >>> are
> >>>>> not compatible with th=
e mother, that is, when their compatibility
> >>>>> distance is 0.00, try a=
gain. There is another possibility, simply
> >>>>> every mutation disturbs =
the CPPN and therefore the produced
> >>> network is
> >>>>> changed in suc=
h a magnitude that is has no chance for survival and
> >>> is
> >>>>> disca=
rded. Even though there is speciation.
> >>>>> 
> >>>>> Peter
> >>>>> 
> >>=
>>> 
> >>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >>>=
>>> 
> >>>>>> Hello all-
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> Does crossover do anything in P=
NEAT and HyperNEAT?
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> PNEAT:
> >>>>>> If I am reading the =
code correctly, during crossover, if the
> >>>>> substrates are
> >>>>>> th=
e same (i.e. all links have the same ID), which is always the
> >>> case
> =
>>>>> in
> >>>>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken from either pa=
rent1 or
> >>>>> parent2.
> >>>>>> Isn't it more normal when crossing over =
to take some from parent1
> >>>>> and some
> >>>>>> from parent2? Why grab =
all from just one?
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> This means that in PNEAT crossover do=
es nothing, right? It will
> >>>>> always grab
> >>>>>> the substrate of pa=
rent1 or the substrate of parent2.  If I track
> >>>>> parent and
> >>>>>> =
offspring fitness, 100% of the time the child has the exact same
> >>>>> fi=
tness as
> >>>>>> one of the two parents.
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> On to HyperNEA=
T:
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resultin=
g offspring.
> >>>>> The odd
> >>>>>> thing is that the organisms that are =
crossed only (i.e. they are
> >>>>> never
> >>>>>> mutated) have the *exact=
* same fitness of one of their parents
> >>>>> 98.88% of the
> >>>>>> time.=
 In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 that were
> >>>>> crossed =
over
> >>>>>> and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would thes=
e
> >>> new
> >>>>> links
> >>>>>> have such a small impact? It turns out t=
hat this is because
> >>> nearly
> >>>>> every
> >>>>>> time that there is =
an extra link that gets placed in the child,
> >>> the
> >>>>> parent
> >>>=
>>> that donated that link is also the parent whose weights are being
> >>>=
>> grabbed,
> >>>>>> meaning that the crossover is only copying the parent =
(hence the
> >>>>> same
> >>>>>> fitness). It seems to me that crossover sh=
ould be much more
> >>>>> disruptive, no?
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> As a=
 final test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs with the
> >>>>> defau=
lt
> >>>>>> 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs
> =
>>> never
> >>>>> are
> >>>>>> candidates for crossover. I then ran experim=
ental treatments
> >>>>>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the
> >=
>> MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>>>> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were c=
rossed over. Despite my
> >>>>> comments
> >>>>>> above, Hyperneat (with cr=
oss) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross, however
> >>>>> the
> >>>>>> difference wa=
s not tremendous (although it does seem to be
> >>>>> statistically
> >>>>>=
> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless,
> >>> this
=
> >>>>> is not a
> >>>>>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends,=
 because if
> >>>>> crossover does
> >>>>>> nothing most of the time, and I=
 increase MutateOnlyProbability
> >>> from
> >>>>> .25 to
> >>>>>> 1, I hav=
e effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
> >>> crossed
> >>>>> o=
rgs are
> >>>>>> also mutated).
> >>>>>> 
> >>>>>> Are these the intended c=
onsequences of crossover, or am I missing
> >>>>> something?
> >>>>>> 
> >>=
>>>> Cheers,
> >>>>>> Jeff Clune

Michigan State University
